ratings.question_text: Which of the following best describes your mode of learning in this course?
options: virtual seminar or other discussion format
in-person seminar or other discussion format

ratings.question_text: Your level of engagement with the course was:
What is your overall assessment of this course?
The course was well organized to facilitate student learning.
I received clear feedback that improved my learning.
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the level of <u>intellectual challenge</u> of this course was:
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the <u>workload</u> of this course was:

narratives.question_text: Please list any other mode(s) of learning, including any combination or variation of the above options.
comments: Live Voluntary Office Hours
In addition to the recorded lectures, there were optional live office hours.
n/a
This was a recorded lecture that had live optional Q&A sessions and office hours.
There were also office hours and live Q&As available.
Recorded lectures with optional virtual live Q&A sessions during class meeting times, along with many office hours

narratives.question_text:
What knowledge, skills, and insights did you develop by taking this course?
(Your anonymous response to this question may be viewed by Yale College students, faculty, and advisers to aid in course selection and evaluating teaching.)
comments:
Statistical Analysis
Minitab proficiency
I now feel statistically literate! I now understand how to conduct regressions and how to interpret them.

Basic statistical concepts like probability and regression, with the latter half it was particularly focused on regression. Honestly these have been super helpful in understanding the statistical methods in some of the readings I have had to do in other classes and with real life data I've encountered.
Statistical literacy in a way that I actually understand now.
Overview of basic statistical concepts with applications and analysis of regression in political science
Basic statistics and how to analyse statistics and experimental data to reach conclusions about an experiment.

I learned how to use statistics software, the fundamentals of statistics, and how to analyze statistics in the context of political science. Additionally, I learned more about what makes a good experiment, and the advantages and disadvantages of various survey studies with regard to statistics.
I learned the fundamentals of statistics.
Learned basic statistical analysis and application methods

My statistical fluency definitely improved a lot (I didn't know anything about stats before taking this class!) and I also learned how to operate statistical computer software which I thought was really cool.

narratives.question_text:
What are the strengths and weaknesses of this course and how could it be improved?
(Your anonymous response to this question may be viewed by Yale College students, faculty, and advisers to aid in course selection and evaluating teaching.)
comments:
Strengths:  A lot of support available through undergraduate teaching fellows.

Weaknesses: Very long lectures with a lot of information that was hard to digest and understand.

Strengths: There were abundant opportunities to receive help and guidance! 
Weaknesses: There was a lot of material to cover, and oftentimes it felt like the first and second halves of the course were totally disconnected.

Strengths: Well-rounded course topics that introduce you to a variety of statistical concepts that are actually relevant to your life. The poli-sci part of the class was actually extremely interesting and done quite well. I liked that the lectures were pre-recorded because there is so much material and I was taking my own notes so I could pause and go back when I needed to. The quizzes in the general part also helped solidify the notes. The TFs had office hours all the time so if you had questions you could almost always find a time to go. 

Weaknesses: There is so much material that it can feel overwhelming if you don't keep up. The psets are kind of long.
Honestly it was fine the way it was. I enjoy learning on my own.

Strengths: recorded lectures made it easier to spread out my time across my other courses. Tons of office hours available made it accessible to reach help. Weaknesses: felt like there was a lack of review sessions, which could've definitely helped

Strengths: Lots of opportunities for office hours, prerecorded lectures made the format flexible, first two exams allowed ample time

Weaknesses: Final exam was quite long given the time constraint, discussion board questions often went unanswered in the second half of the class, prerecorded lectures were often longer than the 2 hour and 30 minute weekly block if the course were in-person

The strength of the course was the lecturers, who were extremely engaging and always very helpful. There were also many resources that were available to help, especially office hours with TAs or lecturers. The weakness of this course was that the online recorded lectures were difficult to engage with and the material was often very dense.

Strengths: the amount of office hours available to students and the feedback given on homework. Additionally, the emphasis on the homework packets rather than solely exams helps with learning the material better. Weaknesses: the asynchronous approach to the course makes it easy to fall behind on class work and exam preparation.

The prerecorded lectures were very good and did a good job explaining the topics. The modules were also organized really well so that it was easy to see which lectures corresponded to each quiz and problem set. A weakness would be that since it was all asynchronous, it was very easy to be disengaged.

A strength was definitely the organization of the class, and how accessible the professors and TAs were. Especially in a semester where people could not be together in the same classroom, it was really impressive and so caring that there were so many office hours held throughout the week (like 60 hours total!). That way, we were still able to build a professor-student relationship and feel the camaraderie of taking a class together.

narratives.question_text: Among the practices in this course geared toward learning during the COVID-19 pandemic, which succeeded and which could be improved? Please comment on course practices that allowed for virtual engagement. (Your anonymous response to this question may be viewed by Yale College students, faculty, and advisers to aid in course selection and evaluating teaching.)
comments: All of the lectures were recorded, however the lectures had a lot of information in them that was hard to interact with and hard to understand.
The whole class was great.

Office hours with TAs and lecturers was a successful component of the course. The online recorded lectures were not an engaging format and if the lectures had been live, there might have been more interest or motivation to watch them.

The practices that worked best are that recorded lectures and notes were available to students on Canvas. Additionally, making office hours available to students at most hours of the day was extremely helpful.

The material and recorded lectures were all very good, but since the class is asynchronous, it was easy to fall behind or not engage much, so some sort of synchronous lecture other than office hours and Q&As would be good.

I thought that having the recorded lectures was really smart and helpful because students could then watch them at their own pace (changing the speed, pausing, rewinding, etc). However, maybe making the recordings live could also be a good option for even more  engagement for those that may want that extra interaction/semi-normalcy.

narratives.question_text:
Would you recommend this course to another student? Please explain.
(Your anonymous response to this question may be viewed by Yale College students, faculty, and advisers to aid in course selection and evaluating teaching.)
comments: I would recommend this course to a student that was really interested in statistics and was able to understand concepts quickly on their own. This is not a class for someone that needs substantial guidance from instructors.
If you need a quantitative reasoning credit and don't have any background in statistics, yes! You learn a lot in a short period of time.

Definitely. It's kind of intimidating even when you are keeping up with the fast pace of the lectures and topics, but the topics are extremely useful and can be applied to a lot of different subject areas and your life in general. The poli-sci part of the class is also really useful for diving deeper into regression analysis which was actually quite enjoyable and interesting, and it focuses on political data sets which was also nice.
Yes, it really helps with statistical literacy. It was an awesome class.

Yes- it is a good course for PLSC majors, as it provides an understanding of statistics in political science studies. The class is definitely not a gut, and you should be prepared to do the work and ask for help

I would recommend this course to students who want to get a basic understanding of statistics, which is important in a range of circumstances. However, the material moves very quickly and can sometimes be a bit dull.
Yes, I would recommend this course to a student if the would like an introduction to the fundamentals of statistics.
Yes, it is an excellent introduction to statistics. It is also not terrifying and well-structured.

Yes, it is a good introduction to statistics and teaches skills that any discipline can use. However, if you aren't motivated to keep up, you might want to take another class because it is really easy to fall behind in this class.

If a student is looking for an engaging way to learn stats, this is definitely the way to go. This class is not dry at all, like one might expect a stats class to be. JDRS is a really dynamic professor and he makes learning stats fun and not intimidating! During office hours JDRS was always patient with students and it was clear that he really wanted to help guide students learning and make sure they really understood the concepts. It was really nice to feel like JDRS was giving us one-on-one individualized time during office hours, even though there were ~20 other people on the Zoom at a time. 

Professor Rader was very well organized in the way she organized her lectures in units, and I liked how she posted them throughout the week so that it was not an overwhelming number of videos assigned all at once. Rather, we could keep up with her pace. I also liked how many real world examples from political science journal articles she used throughout her lectures, which made it easier to grasp the concepts she was teaching. 

I also took this course while taking another political science course where we read and analyzed a lot of political science articles. It was cool to see the overlaps between the two classes (especially when both classes discussed the same studies!) and taking both helped me better understand the content of each class.

S&DS 502 01/PLSC 452 01/EP&E 203 01/S&DS 102 01
        Intro to Stat: Pltlcl Science/IntroStatistics:PolitclScience
